Comment: My grand parents all lived to between 79 and 86 years of age, the last died in 2004. They were from a very different generation as are my parents and myself.

There are marked differences in each of the three generations. My grand parents generation typically lived full active lives right up until their deaths at home. Far fewer of my parents generation die at home from natural causes. Many end up in extended care facilities with multiple health problems. My generation (boomers) are going to see an even larger number in extended care facilities and at an earlier age, its already happening.

Life expectancy is declining in Canada and most western countries.

My grand parents life expectancy was 59 male, 61 female, yet they lived 20 plus years longer. My parents 63 male, 66 female, living less than 20 years longer. My generation 67 male, 73 female and we live closer to 10 years past expectancy.

Comment: Trump had four big domestic priorities when he took office:
• Repeal Obamacare.
• Cut taxes for the rich.
• Spend $1 trillion fixing roads and bridges.
• Build a wall.
The Obamacare effort has already failed. His tax plan apparently won't work with Obamacare in place, so now he's delaying that to take another run at health care. He doesn't have anywhere near enough support for his infrastructure plan, which is why he's desperately scanning the horizon for weird ideas to fund it. And the wall hasn't gone anywhere yet. It may yet make progress, but even Trump admits it won't cover anything close to the whole border.

On foreign policy, he's crashed and burned on his immigration plan; reversed himself on Russia; launched a strike on Syria with no apparent follow-up plan; still has no proposal for defeating ISIS; caved in to China on Taiwan; and has gone soft on trade.

Comment: One thing to bear in mind in the debate over church and state is that Canada is not 'Murica.

America was established with the idea of separation of church and state clearly entrenched in the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.  It is based on the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution which declares that “Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.” 

Thomas Jefferson promoted the idea of such separation and in 1947, U.S. Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black quoted Jefferson in his majority opinion for Everson v. Board of Education declaring that “the clause against establishment of religion by law was intended to erect ‘a wall of separation between Church and State.'”

Many Canadians erroneously believe that separation of church and state is guaranteed in the Canadian Constitution. When, in fact, Canada constitutionally accommodates religion in ways that would never be accepted in the United States.

Comment: With all the snow we have had, roof exhaust vents could have gotten covered with snow.   I would be concerned that snow could have blocked them.  Most exhaust vents are located on the roof, but we have noticed that in some cases the furnace or boiler exhaust was located on the outside wall not more than a foot from the floor of the porch or ground.  I would be concerned that snow could have blocked the exhaust there as well. Also, as someone else mentioned, the freezing fog in the area could have accumulated on the exhaust vent as ice and blocked it that way. It is also possible that ice may have melted and run down the exhaust pipe and refrozen (not as likely), It would be a good idea for everyone reading this to check their furnace or boiler exhaust vents and make sure they are clear.  It could save your life.

Comment: Well some form of proportional representation does give more people a voice and may increase our low voter turnout. But I suppose many think a low voter turnout is also good for stability ....... who wants the fringe and the unwanted voting and disturbing the status quo. Many don't vote because their vote has no influence, no voice (a liberal in Lethbridge, a conservative in parts of Quebec).. 

How about a system that combines both? One vote for the first past the post representative and using that vote for proportional representation. A third of seats for PR based simply on the vote. No ranking, no second votes, no complications. A liberal in Calgary can vote liberal knowing the seat will be lost but their vote will count. You get the stability of the current system, but every vote has an influence.

Comment: Re. "new texts, in addition to the old ones, to reflect a changing student body." How many new texts can you add before you start pushing out the old ones that have stood the test of time and are recognized as *literature*? And how do you know the new texts are not just ephemera added to satisfy political expediency? 
Cleansing the canon is old hat. In university English, it began in the 1980s, when Toni Morrison began displacing the great William Faulkner, because he dealt so frankly with race, albeit sympathetically. 
Re. "a school official reportedly said To Kill a Mockingbird may make some uncomfortable." The school official perhaps doesn't see that one of the main functions of literature is to make readers uncomfortable and to *criticize*: when one is uncomfortable, one thinks. The unfamiliar, not the familiar, makes us think. Heart of Darkness and 1984 made many of us very uncomfortable. Sadly, not much thinking results when students enter what amounts to a literary echo-chamber.

Comment: Explain climate deniers and the four Tillamook burns,  or the Silverton Hills Fire,  of 1860s,  that burned 900,000 acres.  Was that a climate deal? Eugene's temps were measured in an Almadore like countryside a century ago.  And the same for Phoenix and Los Angeles.  There are  no reliable comparisons,  and on that people want to base "science."  

I have on my lap "Climatology of the United States" by Lorin Blodget,  1857. Pub by Lippincott,  Phila.  160 year old climate records going back into the 1830s, and earlier. Comment: I disagree with your comments.
Firstly, the main purpose of a vaccination is to INFECT a person with the disease, just like catching it from a random person on the street. Only difference is that in the vaccine, the pathogen has been disabled in some way. Under these conditions, the body can create an immune response to the pathogen without having to suffer from the symptoms of a "wild" infection, e.g. pox, swelling, inflammation. So to say that vaccines are making people "weaker" is wrong because they are still being infected by the disease. 
Secondly, vaccines have decreased the incidence of many diseases (info on Measles and how the vaccine help fight it in the US https://science.education.nih.gov/supplements/webversions/InfectiousDiseases/activities/activity5_measles-database.html). Remember when smallpox was a thing? I don't, I was born a decade after it was irradicated, thanks to the help of inoculations and vaccines.
Finally, lower mortality due to lower incidence of disease.

Comment: Our international legal obligations under the various conventions and treaties relating to refugees say otherwise and we have passed them into our domestic law under the 'Immigration and REFUGEE PROTECTION Act'.

In 1985 the SCOC in the case of Singh v. Minister of Employment and Immigration, [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177 determined that "everyone" within Canadian borders (including those without legal status)  have Charter rights and in particular refugee claimants rights under s. 7 that guarantee "fundamental justice (our version of due process).  As a result refugee claimants were given the opportunity to make their case before an independent tribunal.

The case law is clear that even passing " through eight other safe countries including the US before they arrive in Canada" does not disqualify a claim to Convention Refugee status although the Refugee Protection Division is entitled to look at the path to Canada in order to assess the well-foundedness of the fear of persecution being claimed.

Comment: As the article stated, Hydro’s 900-megawatt Burrard Thermal Plant is "the cleanest operating natural gas standby plant in North America," but you are arguing that it's misguided to choose plants like this over the dam. If you ignore the research that dams' reservoirs emit methane gas, this may seem to make sense.

But one thing about generating plants is they can be closed relatively quickly, and indeed, older technology generating plants are being shut down. The closure of the huge Navajo Generating Station in Arizona was recently announced, closing 25 years earlier than planned, and the closure of the Burrard plants proves this too.

But dams? Sorry. but that's a 100 year commitment to operate no matter what new tech comes along. And even if you did want to shut it down and drain the flooded lands, that would also take tons of money, and the drained land would be wrecked for at least a generation. 

The Site C dam would be a permanent, expensive mistake, so let's not build it.

Comment: "The gender often assumed when we see people is based around cis ideals of what people look like, and also assumes only two binary genders exist. When do most people see a person and assume they are non-binary?"

There is a basic saying in medicine, "When you hear hoofs, assume a horse, not a zebra." I.e., assume what is most likely, not the rare occurrence. That is actually what most human beings do naturally, i.e. assume that what happens in 99% of cases is what is going to happen this time, too, instead of assuming it will not. Doing the reverse would make ordinary human interaction impossible.

Comment: Dude, that was 1989. A total speculator's market had driven prices up to silly levels. Toronto was a very different city then. Way fewer people, hardly any immigration, no Raptors, no Opera House, etc. etc. 
Today Toronto is a desirable place to live. The population has boomed and continues to do so. There is a ton of economic activity of every stripe including the film industry which is on fire and generates tons of revenue and creates lots of jobs. As a result demand for housing will be here and the market will continue to mature. Will it increase 25% every year? Of course not, that was silly, but this correction will be tame and will eventually level off and prices will rise at a normal level. And, besides, most people I know want to live in their homes in the neighbourhood and they are not flippers. They are in for the long haul. They like where they live and they don't want to move. If they do it's in the same neighbourhood. Demand will always be here for homes in the city proper.

Comment: My argument is in no way strongest for a single-payer system.  I despise single-payer, for many reasons.  I am free to work for whomever I choose, if they want to hire me.  If I don't like their benefit package, I don't work for them.  I know Hobby Lobby has their religious views mingled with their business management.  If I don't like it, I won't seek employment with them.
A traffic accident can kill me.  Older cars don't have as many airbags.  Should I expect an employer to buy me a late-model car, so I don't get killed in a car wreck, thereby causing them expense to hire my replacement? 
I don't believe in forcing employers to furnish health insurance, then telling them what that insurance must cover.  That is why the cost of insurance increased more dramatically after ACA implementation, than before implementation.  We don't all need the same coverages.  I would rather belong to a pool of low-risk members, than a pool that included high-risk members.  But, that makes me heartless.

Comment: "... by opposing two pipelines that Canada badly needs."
.
Who says so?
.
There are oil companies that want those pipelines, true enough.
.
But they have shown, time after time, that they serve only their own interests, not the interests of Canada or of Canadians.   These are the people who put Stephen Harper in office, remember.  What a decade-long disaster.
.
That foolishness cost 400,000 jobs in manufacturing in Central Canada, and led to the cut in the GST that has now increased accumulated public debt by roughly $180 billion, and prevented the building of critically needed public transit in all of our major cities.
.
When the oil companies have apologized for that disaster; paid down the $180 billion; and new transit has cut commute times by 30 minutes everywhere, then we can discuss pipelines.
.
There is absolutely no evidence that Canada would be better off by building those pipelines.  There is lots of evidence we would be better off without the oil companies in question.

Comment: I have been in the Canadian Consulate in San Francisco.  It took two days to get a travel permit after my passport was stolen.   However, it is manned quite adequately by American staff.  I had to return a second day to get approval to return to Canada on a travel permit, and  I had to book a hotel for an extra day at San Francisco rates.  What struck me is the three hour time difference with Ottawa. 
Though officials work a full shift, Ottawa is closed to them for the afternoon.   They are only effective starting at 9:00 (noon Ottawa time) and finish at noon when the offices in Ottawa close. 
Because of this time difference, it is a one half work day.  Moreover, San Francisco is not an Embassy; it is a trade consulate with low status in the foreign service.  There are a number of services they cannot offer.  This appointment is a part-time position at double the pay.  The Consul General's job is very soft.  It is not Gerald Butts money to give away.  It is mine and yours.

Comment: Exactly right, Mike AA.  One cannot do a good job when trying to satisfy two opposites of goals. The overall goal should be in creating a beautiful, clear, understandable and inviting ritual that truly includes celebrant and congregation equally.  Our liturgical music needs major rehabilitation as well.  Get rid of all of the "cantor sings and we respond with one line" most don't bother to even try and sing.  There is literally volumes and volumes of great music written over the past 50 years, sitting in rooms collecting dust.  We really don't have far to go in this, just a useable framework from the USCCB and let the rest of us get to work!  So many have been waiting to do so for decades.

Comment: I believe that most Canadians (rightly or wrongly) would probably support further increases in debt if that money was used to reduce some of the many social problems that we have in Canada and if it was not tied into higher taxes and user fees.  
Unfortunately, it seems that the policy is to expand the size of government, to increase taxes, and to spend millions of dollars on new programs to support the disadvantaged in other countries while ignoring those in need in Canada. 
As with all polls, the answer received depends entirely on the questions asked and the manner in which they are framed. The choices here appear to have been the more extreme option to balance the budget (presumably at the expense of existing programs and/or tax increases) or to allow the debt to grow providing that it does not increase the ratio between debt and GDP. 
Clearly those are not the only choices and the vast majority would have chosen something in the middle - a result that the pollster did not want.

Comment: I feel this is written by someone that doesn't get it, and interviewing old-school auto execs.

No one wants to buy an EV?  Half a million people ordered a Model 3 before even seeing it.  Rural will be 10 years behind city?  Rural has almost 100% capacity to charge at home whereas many city dwellers won't for a while.  Range limitations?  We're at the cusp of massive introduction of models that will compete with, and exceed, the current ranges of the Teslas and the Bolt.

The challenges are 1) dealership legislation limits distribution channels, and the current dealership business model has strong disincentives to support EVs; 2) battery manufacturing capacity may not be economically viable in Europe and will need to be sourced from Asia, further hitting traditional ICE jobs in Europe; 3) total buy-in by the auto execs and their boards.

Charging infrastructure as a problem is actually more perception than reality.  Charging is mostly at home, and increasingly available at work.

Comment: It is worth emphasizing two changes rushed through yesterday by the Trump Administration.

One change removes restrictions on coal mining companies, freeing them up to pollute streams and forests with the waste from coal mining.

The other change keeps it private when American oil companies offer huge, bribe-like sums of money to overseas officials to get access to oil fields, removing a previous rule that required such payments to be publicized.

It is unclear how any Trump supporters would "sell" those policy changes to regular, everyday voters. Indeed, both rules are going to benefit the top one percent (suit-wearing executives at the coal and oil companies), not the little voter guy whose family fishes or drinks water from the streams, or who wants more clean, home-grown energy independence for America.

(... and pardon the sexist analogy, obviously there are executives who wear blouses and there are moms who take their kids fishing and so on.)

Comment: This is clearly written by somebody with no real knowledge of the court system. Judges and lawyers do much of their work outside of court. The average judge works 60-70 hours per week as it is, while sitting in court for 20 of those hours  (five hours per day, four days per week on average). If court sat for forty hours per week, then the judges would probably have to work 100-120 hours per week; this is impossible. The standard one and a half hour lunch break is there mainly for the court clerks, who always have paper work to be done after  court  adjourns but before they get their lunch break.

Courts DO sit all summer; jury trials are usually not run during the summer, but judges are there, as are lawyers. In any case, judges are equivalent to senior executives, for whom five or six weeks holiday a year is common.

Courts make extensive use of modern technology; gowns don't slow things down a bit.

Comment: Please lets not neuter opposition and / or curtail public debate. Canadian Parliamentary procedure is a proven system that has worked well for 150+ years. Once upon a time, citizens of a country who let their actor of the day unilaterally change their rules got far more than they expected.  My Dad, Father-in-Law, and many cousins voluntarily took a 5 year tour of Europe to put it right, and at far more expense than a few more days of debate.  Lets not go down that path. Son of Fuddle has the same tools his father had to table and enact his agenda. If it takes a few weeks longer to listen to other points of view - well too bad, its Our Canadian Way. Comment: This is, in effect, a public relations piece for the wind energy industry.  Predictably, there is no mention of what happens when the wind is not blowing. What back-up electricity generating facilities have to be built to deliver electricity to the grid when the wind is not blowing, not blowing sufficiently, or even blowing too hard (since the wind turbines have to be shut down in these instances)? 
 Similarly, no details are provided of  the taxpayer subsidies being provided to the wind energy producers.  There is always taxpayer money involved.  The critical question is how much?
As well, there is false comparison: "In just two years, the cost of generating electricity from offshore wind farms has fallen by nearly 50 per cent and the latest projects will be 40 per cent more cost-effective than the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station, which is under construction in Somerset, England." Nuclear plants deliver electricity all the time; wind turbines only sporadically.

Comment: The promise of electoral reform was the single most important promise made by the Liberal party in the last federal election. If they do not intend to honour this commitment, then I think it is up to the Liberals to explain why they think it is reasonable to maintain a dysfunctional and perverse electoral system that hands 100% of the power to a party than gets the support of just 24% of the electorate (or 39% of votes cast), and which devalues most votes and while overvaluing a small number of votes in swing ridings. Most Canadians are effectively disenfranchised by first-past-the-post, and there is in practice little point in voting for most of us - which is one of the reasons that fewer and fewer of us are voting. FPTP is a perverse relic of the British Empire that is well past its best-before date; it is time that Canada joins the vast majority of parliamentary democracies and brings in a proportional system in which all votes, and voters, matter equally.

Comment: When I lived in Rome, I used to attend services at the Cistercian (Trappist) abbey of Tre Fontane. I've always been impressed by the Cistercian Reform of the Cluniac Liturgy, which consisted of stripping the Liturgy of all additions and celebrating it as it was meant to be celebrated, without accretions. The prayers are said with great respect, not intoned, and the parts meant to be chanted are chanted, not recited. Each gesture has a meaning, and no gestures are added. The result, in my opinion, is a Liturgy that speaks for itself: both simple and powerful, and one that doesn't require innovation. I think we've lost that in our parishes and we try to compensate by belting out the Lord's Prayer and holding hands.

Comment: It takes a comprehensive understanding of how goods and services are distributed in Oregon to understand that a gross receipts tax on all revenue of $5 million or more is going to be layered in the distribution of goods and services.   The consumer does not pay a passed through straight 0.95%.  No.  They will pay the accumulated tax from each participant in the distribution of the goods and services,  which can be as much as 5% compounded in the end.

Your health care will be taxed at the hospital and/or doctor level.  Your fuel will be taxed at a minimum of three times,  or a 3% or more tax on gas and diesel.  Your food will be taxed by at least three levels of handling the products,  and the tax will be more than the profits or markup on the goods and services for high volume,  very cost competitive commodities like groceries, fuel, and rents on larger operations.  You must know that it is,  in reality, a 3% to 5% or more sales tax to be paid by all consumers.

Comment: 2/2
I notice that you attach great importance to what the Founders “dreamed”, or didn’t dream.  Is that a term of art in the law?   The founders were fully aware that they could not conceive (or dream, if you prefer) of every issue that would confront their descendants.  The genius of the Constitution is precisely that it is an instrument of governance devised in the eighteenth century with sufficient elasticity to serve as the foundation of law and government in the twenty-first century.  Most of us never dreamed that we would live to see the right of same sex couples to marriage affirmed.  Many in my grandfather’s generation never dreamed they would see the right of persons of different races to marry affirmed. The greatness of our country is not that these expressions of bigotry lasted as long as they did, but rather that we have a system that finally righted the wrongs. The United States really is a great country, but not a perfect one.

Comment: No historical event has intrinsic meaning.  Their meanings arise only from context, and since some events have multiple possible contexts, multiple meanings are found. The French Revolution, for example, has undergone at least four great interpretations, the revolutionary-republican, the Catholic-royalist, the Marxist, and finally the as the French civil war, between Paris and the countryside, that created the modern French state.  

Similarly, our Civil War has always had multiple meanings.  It was the war to save the union, and the war to end slavery, but not necessarily to the same people.  Later it became the tragic war between brothers (as if it ever could have been avoided!).  Now it is resurrected as only the apparent defeat of white supremacy.  The many Confederate monuments that have been hiding in plain sight for nigh on a century are suddenly discovered to be evidence of this.  They will be pulled down.  But that will not end the war.

Comment: "But no let's lock them in a room or steal their property."

The issue here is approaches to misbehaviour and whether force, including hitting, is a suitable response. 

You have put a spin on two common and effective responses. A "time out" provides time for a bit of reflection and maybe a much-needed nap. You view it as forcible confinement. In the adult world (and I often reminded our students of this) some degree of confinement is almost a certainty for most offences: if you or I threaten, steal, damage property, etc the police will be summoned and we will soon find ourselves in the back of a cruiser.

Removing a cell phone from a kid who's still texting at 2 AM on a school night is not theft, it's the logical consequence imposed by a parent who knows that their kid needs an education a lot more than he needs an addiction to electronic gadgets. In the adult world, if you or I are liable for damages because of our irresponsible behaviour, we lose stuff: money and often much more.

Comment: You are mistaking a real Trust versus the Permanent Fund.
"Alaska Constitution Article 9, Section 15. Alaska Permanent Fund 
At  least  twenty-five  percent  of  all  mineral  lease  rentals,  royalties,  royalty  sale  proceeds,  federal  mineral  revenue  sharing  payments  and  bonuses  received  by  the  State shall  be  placed  in  a  permanent  fund  the  principal  of  which  shall  be  used only for those income-producing investments specifically designated by law as  eligible  for  permanent  fund  investments.  All  income  from  the  permanent  fund shall be deposited in the general fund unless otherwise provided by law."
So, in summary, you have the right to fight for an individual cash dividend through the legislative appropriation process. However the Legislature is prohibited through Article 9, Section 6 from spending broad based tax income to finance it.

Comment: Not a particularly bad piece, but not an especially good one, either. Yes, changes brought in during the 1960's and 70's were in part a consequence of changes in Canadian society during the time; however, there was also an expedient and improvised character to them as well. If we accept that Canadian identity is founded on the pillars of official bilingualism and multiculturalism, we must further acknowledge what this has rendered: a paradoxical nation where one can celebrate his/her ethnic identity---but only in two official languages. In turn, this has also spawned a double standard as to how English and French Canada views our collective identity. Sadly, too many Quebecois to this day entertain the conviction that while both pillars apply to English Canada, only official bilingualism pertains to them. 

While I wouldn't argue that official bilingualism and multiculturalism are failures, I don't think we should harbor illusions about the consequences of what both have bestowed to us.

Comment: On no!  Laws might change!  

Not to worry.  Why not to worry?

Try thinking of a law that the majority (read:  the MAJORITY) of the public want abolished, immediately.
Anything from the smallest traffic laws to any law debated by SCOTUS.

There are none.   The reason?   In a democracy, lawmakers invariably only enact laws that the majority will agree with and abide.  And any law that the majority of citizens disagrees with cannot long stand.  This has been true since our nation's founding.

We assume that we're at the mercy of our lawmakers.  But actually, our  lawmakers heed public opinion more than abstract legal reasoning.  

So if you're worried that abortion will be outlawed,  it's simply not going to happen.   

Why?  Because since 1970, the percentage of the public who want abortion outlawed has always been less than 20%.   That is the true reason for why abortion is legal -- majority opinion of the public.  Particular judges only seemed like the reason.

They are called volcanic calderas.  The writer lives close to one with Okmok relatively close to the SE of Unalaska. OTOH, they will not survive the commercial nets.  Cheers -

Comment: On corporate taxes that is true, but the US has THE highest corporate tax rate in the OECD. As for top marginal rate, we are the third lowest amongst province and territories (Only Nunavut and Northwest Territories are lower although Saskatchewan will be next year), but when compared to the US, our top marginal rate is 47.7%, which is higher than over 40 states in the US.  Their top federal rate is 39.6% while ours is 33%, but their typical state tax rate is usually around 5-7% thus average top rates between 45-47% so slightly lower than us. Comment: 76,000 Liters sounds like one tank car ruptured, and lost about 2/3 of its load.  When a pipeline ruptures, (pipeline leaks are a bit less than half as frequent as tank car derailments), the typical loss is about five times that.
.
While pipelines leak less often, each leak tends to be much bigger.  Overall, railroad tank cars and pipelines are about equally risky for the transportation of oil.  There isn't that much to choose between them.
.
But, to put it into perhaps more meaningful perspective, they are each more than a hundred times safer than shipping by tractor-trailer on the highway.

Comment: In Canada, the rBST growth hormone was forbidden on animal-welfare grounds, not for health reasons. Health Canada's position is that it has *no* negative impact on humans through milk or meat consumption. This falls squarely in line with the conclusions of other national and international health organizations.

In fact, Canadians have probably consumed milk from rBST-treated cows without knowing it. We import millions of kilograms of dairy products from the United States annually, and at least some of those imports were likely produced by hormone-treated cows.

But I have to congratulate Canadian dairy cartels for how they portray this. They've taken what is basically an animal-cruelty regulation, and used it to defend their market position, proudly proclaiming Canadian milk as hormone-free, with the implication that American milk is unsafe or dirty. This is dishonest, but it does seem to have struck a chord with some people.

Putting our healthcare into the hands of private industry is a terrible idea; It makes no sense to put your healthcare into the hands of people that have a vested interest in keeping you sick.

If your medical expenses were simply paid for you would wipe out the endless litigation that our courts have to deal with over medical expenses, you could take the VA out of the medical game (most vets would like that idea), and you could live your life without the fear of being ruined by medical bills.

Comment: I find this issue interesting if only because of the position taken by the writer that enforcing our laws should be suspended if they are broken by those  providing media. I think particularly of the 'intellectual property' laws wherein artists' and authors' works are supposedly protected from theft but are stolen routinely. I certainly believe in freedom of speech but I also have trouble with the notion that the the conveyance of material deemed to have been created or presented illegally should be allowed to continue after the courts have prohibited it. There is an element of anarchy in this belief that is disturbing given that our civil society is governed by rule of law. Allowing the conveyors of illegal content to do so without care for prosecution simply doesn't make sense no matter what the technicalities or difficulties of removing such content entails. There are no acceptable philosophic or moral rationales that transcend the need to subscribe to the laws in question.

Comment: I am a 75 year old product of the "old Toronto" (largely Protestant Christians) whose grandmother was discriminated against when she arrived in Canada in 1908 (by signs in stores advertising sales vacancies but stating "no Irish need apply"). Yet, my grandmother was also a member of the Orange Lodge, which discriminated against Roman Catholics.

Until I entered U of T, I had never talked to a jew or a black. When I did, I found them acceptable as friends. In 1968, while interviewing job applicants, I met my first Sikh. I had to mentally talk to my self to concentrate on his words and not on his appearance. He turned out to be a fabulous employee. In time, my department expanded to include both a muslim and a Chinese Canadian woman - all of which added to its strength.   

I have become used to muslim women wearing the hijab. But, I still am uncomfortable with the niqab. Why? I suspect because I have not yet had a meaningful personal interaction.

Time is the answer; not a ban.

Comment: Theological illiteracy among Catholics can be blamed, at least in part, on the culture of paternalism within the Church. The hierarchy still supports a top-down method of pedagogy, even for adults. (Even the word "pedagogy" implies a model of learning suited to children.) If that's the system one is formed in, it doesn't make for robust adult faith but, rather, theological dependency. 

As for Scriptural illiteracy, until the mid-20th century, Catholics were discouraged from individual reading of the Bible. The idea was that the laity weren't equipped to understand Scripture without the help of the clergy, and that our time to be nourished with The Word of God was during the homily at Mass. The Church still holds that homiletics is the primary mode of Scriptural catechesis for adults. The problem is that too little emphasis is placed in seminary formation on good homiletics, and it shows.

Jesus played with the children and taught the adults. We do it the other way around.

Comment: Nanakanada:

1. From where did you draw the statistic that "15+ million [sic] Canadians are addicted to booze"? That would be some 40% of the entire population.

2. Many universities try to put restraints on the use of alcohol on campus; strict licensing requirements are in place for any function with alcohol. Gone are the days of 'boat races' and other drinking contests. Most alcohol consumed is off campus, where universities have little or no control.

3. With most students entering university after Grade 12, this means they are usually underage for their first year, and some for part of their second.  How these students gain access to alcohol is again beyond the university's control.

It is a social issue more than anything else. Where McGill could have been more active would have been to suspend all team members responsible, both from the team and academically. This would have sent a strong message that such behaviour - regardless of whether it included alcohol - was unacceptable.

Comment: There is already going to be another telescope in Chile.  But since Chile is below the equator it can only observe the Southern sky.  That's one of the reasons Maunakea was chosen: it's the best spot in the Northern hemisphere to observe the Northern sky.  It's location in the middle of the pacific makes it generally the best in the world to do astronomy since the air flowing over it is less turbulent and causes less twinkle in the incoming light.  So while you might be correct that there are other places, you are incorrect that there are better places for the TMT.

Also your comment on the "typical American" comes off as very bigoted.  Americans, Polynesians included, are the most diverse group of people in the world, with ethnicity, religions, and cultures coming from all over.  To say their only sacred space is their financial institution is to demonstrate a profound ignorance of what the fabric of America is really made up of.

Comment: I've said they paid zero USAGE-BASED fees/taxes, not none at all.  Everyone pays those non-usage general fees/taxes, whether they drive or not, whether they ride a bike or not, whether they ride transit or not, etc.  There's a lot of value roads add to the community by enabling emergency response, construction, utilities, shipping, deliveries, general commerce, etc. that benefit residents even when they're not on the roads.

But as for people using the roads THEMSELVES, it's pretty much 2 categories -- motor vehicles, and bicycles.  And that's the part where a fairness factor can be applied to people paying (at least part of) their own way for their usage.  Use more, pay more; use less, pay less.  That's what motor vehicle registration and gas taxes do.  It's only fair that bike riders kick in a little of that usage-based funding too for the roads that they're sharing with cars (and arguably more than a little for any dedicated bike lanes/paths that only they're allowed to use).

Comment: No problem at all. The United States began when former separate colonies united in opposition to British rule. Absent the crown's authority, those separate colonies considered themselves independent states. They were persuaded to join a union of such independent states- the United States of America- by allowing them to retain a great deal of control over their own government, laws and social order. That included the existence of slavery.

Getting rid of slavery had to happen, but you can see how doing so would draw huge resistance in those former colonies where it was deeply ingrained in the economy and culture. T slave states had a justifiable political grievance- the principle under which the union was first formed was being usurped. Their way of life was about to be overthrown, and obviously that wasn't the reason they signed on to the Constitution.

Global cooling is myth: http://physicstoday.scitation.org/do/10.1063/PT.5.8199/full/

Comment: OK, I see a problem here.

There are 14 candidates. Voters can rank order their top 10 preferences.  The likelihood, it seems to me, is that a great many voters will not get beyond 5.

So after 4 rounds we lose the bottom 4 who might have 5% support between them.  A couple of more rounds and there is maybe another 5% to divvy up.  2 more rounds, maybe another 10%.  At that point, no candidate is over 35%.

So onto Round 9.  And 10.  And 11. At this point, the total number of votes to be counted starts to decline noticeably as many people have not made 7th, 8th, 9th and 10th choices.

The result will be that the winner ends up with far fewer than 50% of the votes of all people who cast a ballot to begin with (maybe 40%).

What a mess for the Conservatives that will be.

Comment: The editor emphasizes the good attributes of Sir John A. MacDonald, even though he was clearly and explicitly a racist. Yet if you propose looking at America's racist leaders of 150 years ago in the same broader way, the editor will have none of it. Despite any good the American leader may have done, according to the editor he is still defined by his racism. Surely you see the double standard?

As most sensible people will acknowledge, pulling down a monument dedicated to a racist of 150 years ago is a symbolic act. It's not so much that we're passing long-delayed and posthumous judgment on an individual, which can be difficult enough to do even for one's contemporaries. Rather, we're engaging in a symbolic act of condemnation against a negative attribute that person had- in this case racism. So if we're calling on America to show its symbolic disapproval of racism, then we should be prepared to show our own. 

Take down S-JAM's monuments, or wallow in the hypocrisy Mr. Editor.

Comment: Let's not call it greed, Professor Haycox, let's call it individualism because that's what it really is in non-partisan terms. It is not everyone's cup of tea, but at the time it was conceived a couple of centuries ago or so, it was very new, and it served as an immense magnet to immigrants from Europe. 

Although there are plenty of examples of greed in our society, it is a fact that Americans want the same things that hominids have wanted for the past million of years or so: a safe place to have a family, resources to feed that family, and freedom to do what we want to do. We Americans are genetically predisposed by our immigrant roots to fight for these things a little more forcefully that others would. Comment: You forgot to mention that the ACLU was also an intervener in 2010 in support of Citizens United law suit, where the US Supreme Court decided that money is a form of free speech.  Like many free speech zealots, the ACLU was unable to see the wood for the trees.

There is no such thing as ABSOLUTE freedom in any human civilization, and I think we should stop pretending that there is absolute free speech until something goes wrong.  The known and predictable consequences of unfettered free speech need to be accounted for before the fact.  I admit limiting free speech is very difficult, but I think it is irresponsible not to do so.  Although Canada is more restrictive, the US does not have unfettered free speech either.

If free speech is the be all to end all in support of democracy, consider how the Citizens United decision has undermined democracy.  It is no longer one man/woman one vote, but one dollar one vote.  The US is no longer a functional democracy.

Comment: For those who have an interest in private equity I would recommend taking a look at the U.S. BDCs (business development companies) - think 'publicly traded private equity'.
No issues with money being tied up for years as they are publicly traded. No need to be an accredited investor.
A couple of suggested names to take a look at - ARCC, GSBD, MAIN.

For most BDCs the majority of their investments comprise debt of private companies with some equity. They are more yield plays than vehicles that will provide potential significant capital appreciation.

I've held the three stocks mentioned and several others for years.

Comment: It is amazing that we would encourage "taxing" our community in the form of a bag fee that would go back to the retailer. It amounts to an added charge to customers that is unnecessary and just nickel and dimes consumers. Further, such a bag fee is unfair to those who are struggling to just buy their basic necessities. On the other hand, the affluent would not be affected by such a fee as that is chump change for them. We already have a regressive tax in the form of the excise tax that adds a burden to those on low income and the elderly living on a fixed income. To ban biodegradable bag is simply ludicrous as we fill the ocean with many non-biodegradable items such as aluminum cans and other plastics. Many consumers used those biodegradable bags to line their waste baskets. Now, consumers have to purchase plastic bags that are not as degradable as those biodegradable bags to dispose of their waste. The problem is not with the biodegradable bags and it should be an exception, period.

Comment: Just to be clear, the issue is not “that a papal statement might have been ‘slightly confusing”. What has occurred is that two diametrically opposed interpretations have been put on it, with some bishops - Germans in particular - making public statements that indicate marriage is not indissoluble. The Holy Father has made indications that have only added to the confusion.

It is the Petrine role to provide guidance to the bishops, so a request for a clarification cannot be characterized as “try(ing) to draw the Holy Father into a media false fireworks show”.

While Mr. McElwee’s reporting might leave the impression “this step by these four cardinals is a new watermark”, it is not. The Acts document similar confusion on the Church’s teaching and calls from the Apostles for clarification. That is their role, and answering is the Pope’s.

Comment: I hesitate to use Wikipedia, but here's a source that appears to be fairly well documented and supports what I wrote. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defensive_gun_use
I agree that the defensive use of an AR-15, or any rifle for that matter, is rare. Handguns are heavily favored. However, if defending a home, a rifle, including AR-15s can be made readily accessible and is highly effective. As to accuracy, a rifle, AR-15 included, is far more accurate due to the significantly longer sight radius; the distance between the front a rear sights. Semiautomatic rifles, such as the AR-15 are capable of firing many bullets in a short time, just as are semiautomatic handguns, caliber 9mm parabellum specifically, that commonly are equipped with magazines that will hold 15 to 17 cartridges. There are some extended handgun magazines that will accommodate even more. The AR-15 is a very popular rifle used in various ways and rarely in mass murders. So why penalize the many for the acts of a few?

I AM an organic farmer - and these kinds of products are produced without toxins or chemicals all the time. In fact they are third party certified to be so, i.e. genuinely organic, not just said to be so!

The compounds in the buds and flowers are in ALL the qualities of cannabis and can be extracted easily without toxins of any kind and blended to make any combination of cannabinols that you may require. And third-party certified as organic.

Of course, if you want to "smoke" cannabis, and as a smoker partake of the organoleptic experience it can give you - then fine, go ahead. Comment: Ten years ago, my husband developed an autoimmune form of arthritis. We knew what it was because his mother has it, but since we were not insured - I was in a waiting period before qualifying through my work - and preexisting conditions would place a yearlong hold on coverage under my employer's insurance plan, we did not dare go to a doctor until we were covered. Because of this, he spent a year suffering from an untreated degenerative disease that left him barely able to walk. He spent most days sitting in a chair. Once he was diagnosed, and after the insurance company had (literally - we heard about it from friends) called every relevant doctor in town to confirm that he had not been diagnosed before, he received treatment that changed him from chair-bound to walking overnight. 

My husband has a chronic disease. Treatment is prohibitively expensive without coverage. A return to lifetime limits and preexisting condition clauses could make him uninsurable. We need the ACA.

Comment: We had similar conflicts but pressure was put on our Borough who is the governmental shelter/protection rogram here. They have the enforcement of all animal related issues, including protection of animals (removing animals fro abusive people) investigation of complaints on noise (dogs barking mainly) and smell from animals, enforcement of our leash laws on beaches and public areas except for the Tongass National Forest (federal laws apply) . On state land or at one of our state parks, the State of Alaska does the enforcement. Any sea protected sea mammal found injured come under NOAA. The injured or dead raptors such as Eagles and Ravens re protected by federal law and come under US Fish and Wildlife. Because the shelter here was a kill shelter, the volunteer groups here worked together to insure that pets were taken care of in foster homes until they were re-homed. The same groups are committed for the spay/neuter of all mammals. Education/Prevention presentations in schools are done.

Comment: I accept the premise that sexism can take subtle forms and is still a major problem in U.S. society. I also accept the reality that women candidates for public office have some unfairly high bars to clear in terms of public perception. But I don't think the problem is that the voters aren't ready for a woman president. I think the problem is that an awful lot of them weren't ready for Hillary.

I just want to be very careful not to overgeneralize about what happened in this election. The temptation is to go all in on the narrative that Trump exploited all these negative impulses in people and that's why he won. That's partly true, but I think there's more to it than that. 

Like it or not, a lot of good, decent people voted for Trump -- or, perhaps more accurately, voted against Clinton. That's something we shouldn't dismiss or oversimplify. If we do, we're just asking for the same thing all over again in four years.

Comment: You think the law is strictly what is written in the laws/regulations?  It's called "case law" and it's the body of prior legal interpretations of judges.  And their educated opinion IS the law.  This isn't true/false, there's no one single right answer.  It is entirely possible that nobody will be accountable under the law here.  It's possible the electronic collar is a reasonable method of control, even for a dog with known issues.  Simultaneously, it's also possible the shooter reacted reasonably in defense of himself and his family.  As far as the dog owner's choice of restraint method goes, it's not illegal for me to leave a loaded gun lying around for my kids to find, it's just highly inadvisable.  If the owner knew his dog had issues, I think he had a responsibility to use a more reliable method of restraint.

Comment: Batteries are only a partial answer as I posted elsewhere.Fuel cells will provide a means to translate energy storage into usable energy even though they do not usually work at the 90% efficiency level as batteries might.
Transmission as useful and cost effective link:www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/01/better-power-lines-would-help-us-supercharge-renewable-energy-study-suggests
Storing hydrogen and using it at the windfarm level is an obvious place once there is enough installed capacity. When there is zero fuel cost storage makes economic sense as it does for nuclear where pumper water storage was used many decades ago and is now being increased.
There are many kinds of storage and future storage will use a combination. Thermal mass/phase change storage is being used to displace peak load times. For example make ice while electric rates are low(or solar or wind in excess) and use it to cool when rates are high. I store heat in mass when the sun shines to use at night or cloudy days.

Comment: a 100ppm rise in CO2 levels will not affect the specific heat of the earth's atmosphere, which varies as temperature changes.  That's a clue as to the lower significance of a modest change in CO2 levels in rising earth temperature, and yes the earth has indeed warmed. So the discussion becomes more nuanced. 

You refer to radiative forcing of CO2. Yet Myhre et al (1998) suggest a doubling of CO2 from 300 – 600 ppm would result in a further ~1.5C increase in surface temperatures. A 100 ppm build would not yield the approx 1.0 deg C increase we've seen in 100 year. Perhaps a 1/3  of the rise can be accounted for that way. 

industrial/aviation/fire/volcanic atmospheric particulates accounts for some of the rise by decreasing the albedo of northern hemisphere glaciers.  Further, impacts from burning 5 million bbl/day of jet fuel in high troposphere is not properly quantified.

Comment: I have a choice of a at least half dozen grocery stores to buy my food.   I can buy clothing from - dozens of companies.   

If I want a phone, I can buy one from Apple or I can choose from dozens of Android devices or even buy a Windows phone.

The market for wireless service isn't quite as wide but at least I have a choice of Verizon, AT&T, T-Mobile, Sprint or some MVNO.

If you want to complain those aren't "truly free markets" I suppose you can but there are plenty of choices.

I have no choice of cable companies other than to subscribe to Comcast's service or not.   I have no choice of DSL companies other than to subscribe to CenturyLink or not.  

I could also get satellite internet or use my mobile phone for internet access, but let's be honest here - those are NOT the same market as cable which is NOT the same market as DSL.

Comment: You do have a constitutional right to bail, (8th amendment) except there are conditions to which it can be denied. For example, if the suspect poses a clear and imminent risk to the general public.Also, in situations where it is likely the accused will attempt to allude the legal process. In these situations, it has been accepted that "no bail" is not considered excessive bail.
.
imo bail should not be provided for an individual accused of new crimes that occurred while out on bail. I also think that denial of bail should be an additional consideration by grand jury during the indictment process for violent crimes. I think that their potential risk to society can be argued by looking at the heinousness of the crime and relationship to the victim(s) (likeliness to be a danger to the general public) as well as whether or not they clearly attempted to allude police when arrested. (likeliness they will appear in court).

2010

Comment: While reading Don Brunell's opinion, I found several errors.
1. Record runs of hatchery fish don't indicate fish recovery. WILD fish runs are still very low & government agencies consider the species to be at high risk of extinction.
2. In 2015 the reservoirs killed 99% of the returning sockeye salmon adults. In 2016, the transport of sockeye smolts killed 88%. We are headed for another "lonesome Larry" situation.  
3. Survival at EACH dam of 97% is irrelevant. It does not measure mortality through the reservoirs. The 4 dams & reservoirs are responsible for killing 30% of the downstream migrating smolts. The 4 dams on the Columbia kill another 20%.
4. The 2015 power production of the 4 dams was enough for 600,000 homes, not 1.87 million.  In 2015, 40% of the power produced by BPA was exported to CA.  So no need to replace it. And if we don't replace it, there would be no additional CO2 emissions.
5. The 4 dams irrigate 13 farms.  35,000 acres. And it would not go away with dam removal.

Comment: "In 1895, the German drug company Bayer marketed diacetylmorphine as an over-the-counter drug under the trademark name Heroin.[70] The name was derived from the Greek word heros because of its perceived "heroic" effects upon a user. Comment: Well, the historical picture is less clear, Gary.  There certainly is much evidence that women deacons existed in the early centuries of both the Eastern and Western Churches.  But there is considerable disagreement about if they were ordained or appointed, and if ordained, just what their functions as ministers were (as opposed to male deacons).  In the Western Church, Women deacons, too, preached the Gospel but only to other women, and went into places where men were not allowed.  The exact history of female deacons - particularly in Roman Catholicism - in muddied with twists and turns, regional and cultural differences, thus the varied interpretations.  By the twelfth century, women deacons disappeared in both Eastern and Western churches, it seems that menstruation was the reason for forbidding women being ordained to any clerical rank.  We need to see what the commission of the female diaconate comes up with and start a new conversation from there.

Comment: If you are a prosecutor, the defendant is well-known and probably not going to run off to Venezuela and you have up to three years to file a felony charge and up to two years to file a misdemeanor, you can subpoena witnesses to Grand Jury to get sworn testimony as to what actually happened and you want to actually win any case that is filed, not just arrest the defendant, 

18 days is hardly 'ignoring' a case.  And when you are talking about Felony or Misdemeanor, that is sometimes the difference between a "Physical Injury:" or a "Serious Physical Injury" as those terms  has been defined in the law and interpreted by the courts.

ORS 161.015 (7) Physical injury means impairment of physical condition or substantial pain.
(8) Serious physical injury means physical injury which creates a substantial risk of death or which causes serious and protracted disfigurement, protracted impairment of health or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily organ.

Comment: Our informational systems (education, news media) fail us if they don't provide the information to understand the various advantages and disadvantages of energy sources. In particular, hydrogen, being produced from fossil fuels, usually either by steam reforming or partial oxidation of methane and coal gasification, is neither efficient nor non-polluting. The best operations lose about 20% of their energy in producing the hydrogen product. And it is hardly pollution-free. One ton of hydrogen produced will also produce 9 to 12 tons of CO2. The common statements that hydrogen is a pollution-free energy source is wrong on two counts--it is neither pollution-free nor is it an energy source.

Comment: The problem with medical insurance in general is that there is insufficient pressure on either providers or consumers to cut costs.  Doctors in Alaska are generally over-paid, and there is no incentive for them to cut their fees.  If there were a single payer system, the single health care payer would be able to bring cost containment pressure to bear on providers.  The other problem is that there is little incentive for consumers to cut costs if they aren't the ones paying - indeed, the pressure on them is to get the most expensive care possible in order to get the most mileage out of their deductibles, and because of the perception that expensive = better.  There needs to be a system in place to incentivize  comparison shopping and price containment for consumers, coupled with price transparency throughout the health care system.

Comment: Psychology, like so many other disciplines, sciences, and technology, is a double-edged sword. It can be used for good and for evil.
Many people today are exposed to the evil side of psychology while surfing the Internet. The popup screens with brightly colored backgrounds accompanied by an alarm and an authoritarian voice telling you that your computer has been infected by a virus and is uploading your financial information at this very moment is an example. These screens are psychologically engineered to induce panic in the user. In a panicked state, the average user is far more likely to do as the authoritarian voice tells them to do. The users simply seek relief from the stress the screen has induced so the thought that this may be a scam doesn't occur to them until it may be too late.
Barring these sorts of uses, yes, psychology, or at least a basic knowledge of it, would likely be beneficial.

Comment: JJ: very seldom does the person who hits the deer pick it up.  Usually it's some guy like me who drives by early the next morning, throws it in his car or truck and hauls it home.  The actual "window of opportunity" for roadkill is very short and most deer are actually hit at night when folks are "going or coming home from the big city."  They usually just say "@#$@#$ it" and drive on.  It's someone else who beats the vultures to that "free lunch."  BTW:  Seldom does anyone field dress roadkill "on site"..You usually don't have the clothes or the tools to do so.  You're not out "hunting" for roadkill.....you happen upon it.....you pick it up, take it home and process it there.  Often roadkill die from broken necks/head injuries and the meat isn't even very bruised.  Gary Crum

Comment: Furthermore, we already have an Infrastructure bank. It is called the Bank of Canada and it operated from 1938 until 1974 with no significant inflation or debt growth and then the Trudeau Senior government allowed it to become autonomous and to market government debts to the private sector creating the present debt that is growing exponentially. When the Bank of Canada holds the debt, the interest on it is returned to the government. The current budget has $24.3 billion allocated for debt service charges and the previous two budgets had $25.7 billion allocated to debt service charges (interest). Since 85% of the debt is held by the private sector very little of the interest is returned to the government. Imagine what could be done with that amount of money! It is the third highest expenditure after seniors and health care and is more than defence.

Comment: As a disappointed supporter of proportional representation, I would like nothing more than for someone to present a persuasive argument for the current system. Unfortunately, this is a poorly written piece that fails in that regard. Despite inaccurately criticizing the "fair vote" movement as unspecific about potential benefits, this article is full of redundant generalized and unsupported claims about the quality of our system, littered with disconnected historical examples. 

The reality is that our system enables a majority government to be appointed by a minority of voters and leaves large numbers of people (with many different views) feeling unrepresented. People disengage from the process and become cynical and angry (see Trump). The cornerstone of democracy is participation; the danger always is to be found in people like Mr. Macdonald who fail to perceive the growing underlying disenchantment and claim that "nothing's broken" as they look wistfully back over the past 150 years.

Comment: Let's have a little thought experiment about Right to Life:  Suppose a woman has an unwanted pregnancy, maybe from a sexual assault, and is denied an abortion.  The child, a boy, is raised in a single parent household with limited means, let's say because her education was interrupted which relegated her to low wage jobs;he has limited adult supervision because she has an erratic work schedule and cannot afford child care. He has trouble in school, for a variety of reasons related to poverty.   Let's say he is bullied as a result and finds companionship in the only group that will accept him, which eventually leads him astray.  

Time goes by, one thing leads to another:  juvenile delinquency, arrest leading to more arrests, prison, falling in with a tougher crowd, then harder crime that eventually involves gun play.  He's sentenced to the death penalty.

This human life is still lost at another human hand, but with other lives lost along the way:  The Law of Unintended Consequences.

Comment: About ten years ago I got records from Linda Lingle for Hawaiian women held in Cornell's prison at Brush, CO. I also got them for Wyoming and Colorado women held there. I paid about $20 for records from each state. 

They'd been horribly abused: An ex-policeman guard had sex with women from all three states. They were moved from there to CCA's Floyd County/Otter Creek prison in remote Wheelwright, Kentucky, where the abuse was considerably intensified. I think they received zero visits in the first year they were there.

The American Correctional Association is equally troubled. It has received harsh criticism for 34 years about its accreditation program which doesn't remotely assess actual operations of prisons. Commercialized, it's hugely supported by revenues from for-profit prison operators such as CCA. The payoffs are equally massive. No matter how badly a for-profit is run, it is certain to pass ACA "standards." Two years ago its president was indicted on 49 counts of corruption.

Comment: I hope our railroad (we own it) finds a way to keep the maintenance schedules from falling behind.  The ARR is a vital link to the interior. As vital as any port that it connects to.  
I hope we don`t let such a gem and attraction languish and become a third rate slow and dying dinosaur.  Our railroad is known the world over for it`s scenery and pioneer aura, as well as being vital to keeping our freight costs down(freight by rail AND water)  on outside goods coming into Alaska.  
  One can complain, like Senator Micciche did, about having to pay for that new auto-braking system, but just remember the recent train incidents that WOULD have been prevented by this system, had they met the FRA installation timelines without seeking multiple delays as we did.  
It`s needed even more so on a single track railroad where passenger trains and freight trains commonly run together in opposite directions, interspersed with crews trying to work on the tracks and bridges and ditches.

Comment: Good afternoon, Jay. Sharp as usual I see:) The oil market is surprisingly simple to understand. Back when OPEC (middle-east version) placed an embargo on oil exports to the US, prices rose. When that happened, any other country that had the chance of oil production, drilled, then went into production. Now, there are lots of producers and they are like Alaska: they can't afford to stop pumping oil because that is how they run their economies (read: feed their people). They have lost the ability to control production.

One would think that the people of Alaska would rejoice in low oil prices. We use the stuff to heat our homes and power our internal combustion devices. To many of us, low fuel prices mean we can better feed our families.

Jay, keep talking, please! We have a lot to figure out. Some of the newcomers (less than 50 years of residence) have a lot to learn about living in our home. Quick verbal slaps might help.

Comment: Because of existing federal legislation, marijuana businesses cannot open a bank account, nor use checking accounts.  The rule is "cash only".  In today's business environment, federal payroll taxes must be deposited online via EFT sites which require bank accounts.  This is an example of one challenge these dispensaries are facing in the battle to become fully operational.  These types of barriers tend to make operating costs exhorbitantly high for marijuana-related ventures.  Change must somehow be made at the federal level, or medical marijuana production and distribution will never be legitimized.  The underground will continue to operate and flourish, generally to the detriment of probably a majority of medical users who are and will be unable to propagate and cultivate the plant for their own medicinal use.

Comment: Yes simple supply and demand. Seems like the trend you have talked about has been going on for some time now of people leaving Hawaii for better lives and getting more for their dollar in the mainland and elsewhere.  Supply and demand controls the housing market.  Prices are high because of a low inventory of houses along with the demand by foreign investors.  If people boycotted luxury condos with their superfluous amenities and high maintainence fees then there would be less of them presently and in the future.  If the demand instead was for more reasonable and affordable condos and living situations the market would dictate that trend.

Comment: It is pure folly to believe that the B.C. provincial government is trying to slow home price growth.  The Federal Liberals increased downpayment requirements on homes over $500,000.  Shortly after, Christy Clark announced a reduction in property taxes on the purchase of new homes under $750,000 that largely offset the Federal move.  The next step for the Federal Liberals was to toughen mortgage qualification rules.  Christy Clark's response?  Interest free downpayment loans to first time buyers.  She did bring in the 15% tax on foreign buyers but that is largely a sham.  The majority of the foreign money in Vancouver real estate comes from people who bought their citizenship in the now defunct Immigrant Investor Programme.  Their money is foreign but they are either Canadian citizens or Permanent Residents so the tax does not affect them.

Comment: No doubt the need is there and likely critical.  A shortage of inpatient  psychiatric beds and psychiatrists is a national problem.   For that unit to work properly, that  hospital would need to budget funds likely far in excess of what they initially determined, otherwise it will either be of questionable quality or be closed in short order due to the hit on the bottom line.  Staffing will be key.  They will need to hire clinicians and not just hope those in private practice will admit to the unit and care for the indigent population which will (and should) make up a significant part off the patient population that will access that unit. Psychiatric units are often a significant loss to a hospital's earnings.  That is one of the reasons you do not see a private company operating one in this area.  

I wish them well...and hope they get the quality of experienced and dedicated staff needed to bring excellent hospital level care mental health services to the Valley.

Comment: I use Whitebird dental and am very grateful for their talent and care.
As a veteran, I use a VA dental insurance program. If one uses the VA system, one cannot use the ACA. 
The VA insurance costs me $250 a year, and the maximum benefit is $500. So one major dental health problem, and that is that for the year.
Not sure many vets know of the VA dental health insurance. The world of medical/dental health insurance is complicated. Many years ago I spent several weeks in agony with a broken tooth, pretty much living on aspirin and waiting for the pain to go away, so I am aware of how important Whitebird dental is to its clients. 
There is a bizarre savagery strutting around Washington DC these days, people saying destroying the ACA is a good thing. I guarantee you one thing, if they had to live with massive dental pain for weeks, they wouldn't be so arrogant.
Still don't get why dental is not seen as medical. The VA ignores a lot of pain as it is dental.
Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

Cupich calls Catholics to focus on what we share in common one with another, and with all people, not to start by highlighting our differences or by noting the speck in our brother's eye."

A noble enterprise, to be sure, but one that will require a generation to undo the damage of Richard John Neuhaus, et al. who worked tirelessly to make the Catholic Church the Republican Party at prayer, a phrase that used to be associated with the Episcopalians. Given the volume of conservative bishops who share Cupich's predecessor's vision, I'd say his noble effort is akin to using a teaspoon to dig a well. Let's hope Pope Francis lives long.

Comment: I can no longer visit family in the San Joaquin Valley without it being a health problem for me. My eyes burn, my throat and chest tighten and if I stay more than 2-3 days in the summer I develop hypoxia no matter how often I hit my rescue inhaler.

Ignore global warming if you must, but don't ignore the very real fact that we are killing people right now every day by clinging to fossil fuels, an outdated technology.

Jesus never suggested tossing aside the ten.  In fact, He said He did not come to abolish the Law and the prophets, but to fulfill them.  Somehow, I think, we gloss over this important passage.

Comment: You'll have to find some supporting evidence for your statement. According to the U.S. Treasury (they keep records), the 2009 tax cuts were some of the biggest in history. Any offsetting tax increases would have shown up in their report (link follows...).

I recommend this document:

https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/tax-policy/tax-analysis/Documents/WP-81.pdf

And this report that was done to show the effects of the 2009 tax bill.

https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/tax-policy/tax-analysis/Documents/WP81-Table2013.pdf

You were also incorrect when you stated that we pay the highest corporate taxes. We have the highest statutory tax rate but our tax code provides generous tax benefits that reduce the overall corporate tax paid to about average for most major economies.

Your statement that the rich pay 90% of income taxes is misleading. While it may be true one could also say they only pay 5% of payroll taxes.  Most of those are paid by the poor and middle class.

Comment: Just recently a number of us were discussing the incongruity of gravel extraction in the Valley. On one hand you have gravel pits everywhere destroying the aesthetic beauty of the country side by turning portions of it into a moonscape. On the other hand we continually read about the plight of road, land and home owners bordering the western portions of the Matanuska River as the river erodes away land and homes.

In the old days, during the winters, the Matanuska River was mined for gravel, providing remedial remedies from the alluvium deposits in the main channels during the summer, mitigating the negative meandering impacts of the river upon adjacent private property. Somehow this changed and that mining activity no longer takes place. Does anyone know what happened?

Our guess is that gravel extraction from all the prime sources on land is much more economical than working the river in the winter, but we are not certain about that.

Comment: That is not what I said. The question is how much real wealth creation has increased since 1986.  Real wealth is created when goods or services are produced at below their production costs as determined by free markets, resulting in a profit.  

Native corps do much of their work providing low value services (hotels for example), which are not rigorous supports for an economy.  Service industries will greatly suffer, just as they did in '86.  Also, they contract for governments, which does not create activities outside of what would be produced otherwise.  This is especially true in the since that many of the contracts are dependent on at least partial state funding, which will be short in coming.

Native corps might "buffer", but how successful they will be in truly deferring economic decline is yet to be seen.  Native corps are involved in some wealth producing projects like Red Dog or the Donlin Project.  

Many would consider 8a contracts welfare, however.

Comment: "The way you know your new production tax needs reform is because the industry says it's working."

No truer words were ever spoken in the hall of the Alaska Legislature.

A lot of people defend the current tax structure by trying to make a big deal out of the fact that under SB21 Alaska receives more in taxes at current prices than it would have under ACES. But this is not an either / or kind of situation. In other words the options are in no way, shape or form limited to either retaining SB21 or returning to ACES. We'd be having the same reform discussion if we were getting pillaged by the oil companies under ACES as we are under SB21. 

Besides, the pro-SB21 crowd told us that if we passed it, tax revenues would rain down on the state and there'd be jobs jobs jobs. They didn't say, "unless oil prices are $54 per barrel", they flat out told us everybody would "win". But the only winner under SB21 are the oil companies. 

I have 3 words for SB21: Repeal and Replace

Comment: If you want current information on flights in our skies or any place in the world check out https://www.flightradar24.com. The site provides a live map showing  ground speed, calibrated altitudes, type of aircraft, stating point, destination etc. of all commercial fights. I am not sure if it is amazing or scary (from an environmental perspective)  at how many flights take place daily over the Alaska skies and the world. But I find it interesting that two flights on nearly the same fight path, at nearly the same altitude and speed can produce two different jet exhaust streams. Take Tuesday afternoon as an example. I counted nine distinct contrails in an east/west pattern over a 2-3 hour period. These jet trails lingered in the sky for hours drifting north with the upper airstreams.  Data from flightradar24 confirmed that 13 fights flew the same flight path, same elevations and speeds during that time frame but only 9 flights left contrails from horizon to horizon. How does that work?

Comment: Question: Should the Westboro Baptist Church in Kansas have the right to go to a graphic art designer (who is gay)and have him design and produce "professional art graphics" that "professionally" portray their anti-gay rhetoric? Does the ACLU say "yes" or would the ACLU defend the right of any art graphics designer to refuse/reject "objectionable" work?
-
In 2014 apparently, the Colorado Civil Rights Division answered the above theoretical question both ways. In one case, they ruled that one baker could not decline to decorate a "gay wedding cake" while in another case, they ruled that a baker could refuse to decorate a "anti-gay cake." Both the real cases and the above hypothetical question involve the question as to whether or not someone can decline to have his/her services "bought" to promote an ideology they are opposed to.
-
And since the CCRD can't seem to be anything but "politically correct hypocrites," perhaps the US Supreme Court will have a field day with the CCRD.

Comment: "This idea could first be tested with the focus on transit and public housing – in Toronto’s case, the most vexatious of current problems."
The public housing part of that could be solved if  Toronto adopted a practice of St Boniface, Manitoba  in the 1930s. It could avoid the hassle and cost of public  housing. It would stop crowding people into small areas.

When people there asked for help for a place to live, they were told to find accommodation at $25,  the going rate for low income housing, or less. (That is when $25 would buy a lot of goods). The city paid the rent. The owner of the houses kept them in shape so that they would rent again and again. All the city had to do was keep a list of residents and addresses to send cheques to. No maintenance. No building. It was all left to the private sector. On the social side, people needing help were scattered throughout the community not ghettoized.

So much lower cost to the city, much better accommodation for the poor.

Comment: 1970-era insurance worked GREAT!  Even the highest level provided by an employer (which is how most people were insured) had huge deductibles, archaic rules about exactly which procedure, drug and length of stay was employed, absolutely NO way to challenge their firm and final decision even when they were obviously wrong, harsh limitations on what constituted a pre-existing  condition.  Many did not consider pregnancy and birth eligible, or had a separate PAID rider...and many covered pregnancy as if it were an illness, and the infant wasn't covered for 15-30 days minimum.  Routine preventative exams weren't covered, the drug formularies consisted of basically aspirin and penicillin, and their paperwork was a nightmare.  The best part was losing one's insurance with every job change, or suffering large diminutions based on employment contract negotiations. The lists of what was NOT covered were 10X longer than those that were covered.

I really want to return to THAT situation!
