Comment: A couple of comments:

Payout ratios can indeed be perplexing/misleading because, as the article says, there are so many ways in which they are calculated.

The most commonly used measure in the media is a ratio based on reported earnings. I believe that this is not a good metric because there can be so many non-cash puts and takes in reported earnings per IFRS.

Using a cash flow metric rather than one based on reported earnings is better in my opinion.  An enhancement this, for those entities that have a material DRIP participation, is to use distributions/dividends actually paid out in cash (i.e. declared distributions/dividends less the amount paid via the DRIP) as the numerator in the calculation rather than declared distributions/dividends.

An example of how misleading some reported numbers can be: This site shows a payout ratio for SRV.UN of 338% - shocking! would perhaps be one's reaction.

Cont.

Comment: You really don't know that in the Early Christian Church---people elected their pastors, bishops even the pope.  Let me cite some references for you.

St. Cypran, a third century African bishop and martyr, recognized the election of Cornelius as Bishop of Rome because he had been "made bishop by the judgment of God and of His Christ, by the testimony of almost all of the clergy, by the vote of the people who were then present, by the college of venerable bishops and good men...."
-----------------
St. Cyprian, "Letters" trans. Sister Rose Bernard Donna, THE FATHERS OF THE CHURCH,  vol. 51 [Washington, D.C.: The Catholic University of America Press, 1964] p. 138.

Patrick Granfield, "Episcopal Elections in Cyprian: Clerical and Lay Participation," THEOLOGICAL STUDIES 37 [1996], p. 41.

Other saints elected to be bishops: St. John Chrysostom, St. Ambrose of Milan, St. Augustine and St. Leo the Great [Bishop of Rome---Pope]

The Presbyterians merely copied what we did in our early days.

Comment: All the measures intended to reduce and fight wildfires assume the existence of a certain climate, but that climate has changed, so those assumptions are no longer valid. 

Fireworks may have been relatively harmless, for instance, when the fire season was two months shorter than now and summer temperatures were lower. Now, in the new climate regime, the fireworks laws strike one as mildly insane. The Eagle Creek burn measures the insanity.

I suspect that neither managed burns nor thinning of forests is going to be beneficial now. The arguments for fire mitigation and prevention that made sense 40 years ago no longer make sense. Context is all; we no longer live in the same climatic context. 

The forest itself is different now too. Plant succession has changed. Soils are drier. Tree plantations of youngish Doug firs are nowhere near as resilient to fire as ancient red cedar and western white hemlock. Maybe only 15% of old growth remains. We need new thinking about fire.

Comment: The "Becca Bill", passed in 1995, envisioned “crisis residential centers" (CRC) as a means of dealing with chronic runaways and other non-criminal offenders. Over 20 years later, CRCs have not been built in useful numbers.
This has created a dilemma for juvenile court judges: let children run free on the streets or use juvenile detention  as a CRC. Judges have chosen the lesser of two evils and opted for keeping children safe from the predators that stalk runaways and street kids.
No, it's not optimum but it may be the best we can for with what we've got, at this time.
Unquestionably, we need to do better. Will this lawsuit help us do that?

Comment: "I am human, and I think that nothing human is foreign to me." Shakespeare is relevant, if approached with respect but not reverence (that might come later, might not). Romeo and Juliet is a great hook, but in upper grades, in a multicultural context, Othello is a stimulating choice. As a teen deals with a faltering grandparent, wouldn't Lear have deep resonance for the student? Part of the great joy of literature and drama is that shock of recognition over generations, that technology changes but we humans go through the same problems century in and century out. It's not just a diversion - it enriches us and can give us the tools to address our lives' pitfalls.

Of course, the teachers are crucial. If they approach Shakespeare as something to be endured rather enjoyed (like poetry, and grammar), it's no fun for anyone. Engaged by turns with gusto and sensitivity, Shakespeare speaks across time and cultures.

Comment: ACTUAL Vision Zero, the way it is practiced in Sweden by its inventor, is quite a bit different than the press-release BS version that Eugene and Portland are pretending to do. Actual Vision Zero operates on the principle that a person should be able to wander out into the roadway blind drunk and not be harmed. The person who started it actually does demonstrations in which he puts on a blindfold and walks backwards into a randomly selected roadway. (This is like the old Roman practice of removing the bracing  under a new archway with the engineer standing underneath it.)

Vision Zero involves extensive law enforcement to train motorists and engineering practices to mitigate the harm done by untrainable motorists (even Europe has some of these). We don't have traffic law enforcement and our traffic engineers/planners are beyond a lost cause; they are ill-trained, unprofessional and not very intelligent. Expect our very high vulnerable road user deaths to continue.

Comment: Actually, there is no way to change someone's sex.  Your post is incorrect to say this, and in that sense there is no such thing as "sexual biotechnology".  Sex is, as pointed out in another reply, chromosomal.  You can change your "gender appearance" via cosmetics, clothing, appliances, operations, and drugs to make your body appear more of a match to who you feel you are.  The technology exists to do that.  But that is not changing your biological sex.  Your post is confusing in your use of the words sex and gender.  Sex IS a "biological imperative" - you have the plumbing you were born with (intersex being a rare exception).  Gender may not be a "biological imperative" in some cases, but is for the vast majority (90%?  95%?  98%?).  As for politics, this is more about too much change, too fast, with too little thought vs.  why can't we change this now since we know this is correct and what is the point of waiting.  All I will say is that "slow down" is the right approach to change.

Comment: Kingwell cautions against a facile, self-satisfied assumption regarding Canada’s virtue.  There’s a broader context.

We’re shaped by uncommon conditions.  We rarely face hostile forces at our borders but live in the shadow of the US and earlier the UK.  We have no dominant cultural group but have had at least two such groups claiming the right to pre-eminence or autonomy during our history.  We are a geographically dispersed society with an urban-rural divide. Etc.

 Consequently, domestic attitudes have swung between two two poles over time but often strike an equitable middle balance.  One is the exceptionalism of the article.  

The other is a depressed reactionary exclusionary miasma that occasionally dominates a region or cultural group and sometimes Canada as a whole. Think of the Orange Order and its Catholic counterparts during the 19th and early 20th century (and also more recent examples).  Isn’t this analogous to the factors that birthed the Trump Presidency?

Comment: It's pilot error because in this case, the pilot was the last link in the chain that caused the crash.  He was physically operating the flight controls and his error in aeronautical judgement resulted in the mid-air collision.  Thus, he is fairly or unfairly the primary cause.  The Aircraft Accident Board may determine that there were other contributing factors such as weather, crew scheduling, fatigue, etc.  However, where the "fun" starts is when the Aircraft Accident Board attempts to assign Supervisory Error within the chain-of-command to those at the top who are supposed to be planning, monitoring, managing, and supervising Fleet-wide-flight operations so that a situation like this never comes about.  That's when all the rats and cockroaches jump ship and deny any culpability.  In short, they claim: "It wasn't my fault.  I'm just the guy-in-charge!"  Marine Corps Aviation has been woefully manged for years.  It's shameful.  Heads should roll, but they won't. That's the way it is.

Comment: The ShakeAlert system is in beta testing in California.  It has demonstrated detection times of 3 seconds, and alert distribution within 4 seconds, warning a few thousands of select users within 4 to 7 seconds, total, of an event.   The warnings are made over point-to-point connections.   The fastest are over already live, internet connections.  This is adequate for many users, such as power stations, rapid transit, etc., that can keep a dedicated link alive, continuously, 24/7.   Nevertheless, alerting a whole population over point-to-point links can't be done.    Radio is fast enough, but the switches and bandwidth necessary to carry millions of independent conversations, simultaneously, makes this mode impractical for alerting the general population.  The alternative is broadcasting a single message, simultaneously, to many users.  Cell towers now deliver WEA's by broadcasts, received by all phones,  simultaneously.   But CTIA doesn't want to speed up uploading alerts to be sent!!

Comment: I understand that a sovereign Hawaiian govt might be able to exercise  more control over in-migration, but it remains an open question in my mind whether or not traditional Native Hawaiian ag production practices alone could support Hawaii's current resident population of about 1.4 million, much less possibly closer to 2 million by mid-century--IF other factors fueling pop growth continue AND Hawaii still cannot directly control its own population growth.

But even if population shrank--say to less than one million again, a level at which local food self-sufficiency was once possible prior to Western contact, colonization, and commodification--it still may not be a certainty that traditional ahupua'a alone could feed all residents again without some imports--especially if climate change beyond local control renders ahapua'a less productive and reliable than in the past.  

Hence, the benefits I see of adding more cost-effective high-tech  production to reach 100% local self-reliance.

Comment: Please check your facts.  UH does not play a "minor league schedule".  There are 774 U.S. colleges and universities that field football teams and UH is among the 130 at the highest level (Football Bowl Subdivision).  UH's future football schedule includes non-conference games against the Pac-12's UCLA, Arizona, Washington, Oregon State, Oregon and Arizona State, the Big 10's Wisconsin and the SEC's Vanderbilt.  UH's Mountain West conference typically puts a team in the Top 25 (3%) each year, including San Diego State in 2016.

Regarding academic standing, the NSF places UH 74th among 895 ranked U.S. research institutions with $316 million in research spending, just behind Colorado State at 73rd with $317 million.  In the Carnegie Foundation research classifications, UH has the highest "R1: Doctoral Universities – Highest Research Activity" rating, the same as Colorado State.  In the USNWR rankings, UH (169th) and Colorado State (129th) are in the same tier of "National Universities".

Comment: What happens if younger people never buy houses? They will be portable (with only one month's notice) and debt free (well, mortgage debt free, which accounts for about 3/4 of all personal debt that exists in Canada). 

Yes, they won't build equity through home ownership, a leveraged investing model that has paid off in the past. But this renting/avoiding debt will give them far better portability in a climate where job security is diminished and wages are low. And, if they have essential skills that a region needs, this portability - plus a willingness to actually BE portable - will give them a lot of leverage to ransom their essential talents. In places where house costs are (increasingly) astronomical, you will see more and more user fees, tolls, etc. to offset the incentives needed to attract and retain critical health care staff, etc. - and you will see services suffer. 

It's very instructive to look at migration trends for people under 45 in places like Vancouver right now.

Comment: Dear Ivo, you say "capitalism" is "characterised" by private property rights, individual freedom to trade in goods, services and labour (leaving aside whether "labour" actually exists as a tradeable entity, or how it might be defined) both at home and abroad, small government, light regulation, and low taxes. May I take this as a definition of "capitalism"? (We know that "capital" itself is something completely different - a set of  to some extent measurable accounting quantities which I think we could all probably agree on in essence).  So, given your definition of "capitalism", can you point to any single nation, country, region, or whatever that could be called "actually existing capitalism"?   Also, are we justified in thinking that people will die because of "capitalism" slower or at least no faster in the future than they have in the past? If so, why?  Is there something absolutely immovably inherently self-limiting about capitalism regarding causing premature death?

Comment: I find it almost 'coup-like' that Parliament has not been dissolved and an election not called on this issue. None of the main parties supported Brexit and most MP's were and likely are opposed. That British MP's sit silent in their seats without demanding to debate - and vote on - the most important national decision since WW2 is unbelievable. 

By any standard this is a Parliament and government that has lost its legitimacy, both because of its pre-referendum position and its post-referendum about-face. Britons have a perfect right to jump off the Brexit cliff if they want to.  But this is exactly the kind of issue that requires an election in the Westminster system. As it is, the supremacy of Parliament is now shown to be just a hollow concept. If British MP's had integrity they would demand a vote to dissolve Parliament, and let the British people elect a new Parliament and government specifically on this issue - one with a clear mandate to proceed one way or another.

Comment: cont.
The hierarchy of the RCC and its faithful Carsons are the "Last Hurrah" of pre-twentieth century aristocratic Europe.
 
Carson: "Why does everyone talk as if we don't live in the modern world?"
Mrs. Hughes: "You don't agree with that, then?"
Carson: "No! Does the King not live in the world of today?  Does Mr. Sargent not paint modern pictures?  Does Mr. Kipling not write modern books?"

Carson: " I don't know. Screaming in the servants' hall, singers chatting to his lordship, and a footman cooking the dinner.  What a topsy-turvy world we've come to." 
Mrs. Hughes: "I think it's exciting. We're catching up, Mr. Carson. Whether you like it or not, Downton is catching up with the times we live in."
Carson: "That is exactly what I am afraid of."

From: Fellowes, Jessica "The Wit and Wisdom of Downton Abbey"

Comment: I would – and will in a later column – argue that the erosion in trust is not because the journalists are doing such a poor job now (for the most part, they actually are doing better journalism than ever before); it's because all sides have become experts at blaming the messenger. Good journalism is the bringing to light – and sharing – of information that people in power, in whatever situation, are trying to keep to themselves. Such an activity attracts scorn from those in power (because they want to maintain the power they have).

Comment: Last time I checked, the world comprised of more than 200 countries, not just the nine in this report.

"there are differences in house types, housing characteristics and lot size between the geographies covered. The Demographia International Housing Affordability Survey does not adjust the Median Multiples to reflect these differences. For example, the average size of housing, particularly new housing, is abnormally small by New World standards in the United Kingdom and Hong Kong."

Don't get me wrong, housing prices in Vancouver have gone up dramatically (I just got my property assessment so I know) but what $1million will get you in Vancouver is greater than in Hong Kong, UK and some US cities. The big difference in affordability is not the housing prices but the low income of Vancouverites compared to he other countries.

Comment: The legal entanglements rest in the difference between a right and an interest. The state intruded on the right of the native Hawaiian as per federal Indian title law to his/her own land as prescribed in America's public land laws. A right is different from an interest, no matter how you parse it. The canoe has zilch to do with the right of native Hawaiians when it comes to their land as the nearest kinship group. TMT has to make a deal with the native Hawaiians and the Bureau of Indian Affairs, not KS(BE) or OHA etc and not with "N"ative Hawaiians or Hawaiians. The state supreme court is not the last stop. The NHLC lost the key case back in the day that would have granted some kind of traction in the current case. I forget the name of it but the NHLC claims they were the embodiment of the spirits of the iwi and had the iwi's own rights.

Comment: OK, let me clarify then. I did think Glenn's comment was offensive and inappropriate, and as I wrote, I flagged it as inappropriate (and did not feel it was worthwhile to repeat it). It was intended to objectify and belittle (and put back into place) a strong woman leader in our country (regardless of what you or I think of her politics). Totally offensive and inappropriate. I'm not sure how that could be more clear. ... Despite my flagging, the system did not remove it (I'm not privy as to why). It still is there now, more than a week later. ... I do not agree, though, that the email prompt encourages a flip response; I really appreciate knowing when someone responds to something I wrote, so I can decide if I want to respond as well. My actions are my responsibility. Sometimes I'm too quick and too loose in my responses, but that's on me. The alternative is that you aren't alerted when someone comments. I think the email alert encourages a complete discussion (rather than a fragment).

Comment: Charles P. Wathen's solution to the affordable housing crisis is problematic because it requires undesirable additional taxes and the conversion of precious agricultural or conservation land to be used for housing.  There's a better solution.  All land that is currently zoned for single family homes from Kahala to Kalihi should be rezoned for low rise apartments, including Kaimuki, Kapahulu, Moiliili, Manoa, Nuuanu, and Liliha.  That would create an economic incentive to increase the supply of housing, which would have the effect of driving down housing prices.  These areas would eventually look more like McCully, where small apartment buildings are mixed in with single family homes.  This solution would increase the concentration of housing on existing urbanized lands instead of destroying precious agricultural or environmental resources, and it wouldn't require any additional taxes.

They are asking for prohibited information: drivers' license numbers, banking information such as branch address, account types, and credit card numbers, excessive employment information.

One must remember that the legislation prohibits discrimination based on how the prospective tenant earns their income.  So therefore asking for employer information beyond "occupation" is prohibited.

Credit checks are also being used excessively these days.  In Vancouver's tight rental market, they are basically selecting from the pool of tenants those with the best credit score, getting 20-40 applications and running them en masse.  In the case of a prior divorce, business failure, or simply hard times, credit scores are not indicative in and unto themselves of anything to do with tenancy.  Often tenants will pay the rent before their bills.

Comment: The danger in discussing Trump's behavior is that it's too easy to get obfuscated by politics. To be fair, the same is true of Bill Clinton. It is clear  both men behaved very badly,  probably criminally so, and neither should be allowed to rationalize away the serious allegations against them as the rambling of partisan enemies.

In the broadest of strokes, this is about the powerful being allowed to prey on the weak, the oldest form of human injustice. In this case, the victims are not inherently weak because they are women, but because of a culture that, despite its claims, still practices male privilege behind closed doors. 

Sunshine is the best -- and probably only -- cure. And it's very hard for sunshine to filter through all the political maneuvering. I pray for truth to win out, and I also pray that this issue isn't forgotten once the election is over. This isn't just about electing a precedent. It's also about addressing a massive societal sin.

Unless you live in the middle of nowhere, a rifle, any rifle, but especially one with a small, high-speed projectile like a .223, is a terrible home defense weapon unless there's a herd of zombies coming down your street.   A pistol with enough stopping power to actually defend you has the same over-penetration problems.   A 12 gauge with 7 or 8 birdshot will kill an intruder just as dead at true self-defense distances as buckshot, a rifle, or a heavy pistol, and it won't destroy your house or kill your neighbors, family, or pets.

Comment: It is already produced. One name is Marinol, class III, and the other is Cesamet, class II. Legalizing pot is not for the purpose of providing medical benefits. It is already legal. Anyone that says different is not in touch with reality, or they need to change doctors that will prescribe it medicinally. Comment: American courts have a long history of making reasonable accommodations for religious groups, but they are always subordinate to the U.S. Constitution and civil law. Halakha is one example of a such an accommodation. Tribal laws allowing the limited use of peyote on Indian reservations is another. One example of an unacceptable religious practice is polygamy which, while still practiced clandestinely by some Mormons, is outlawed.

Some aspects of Shariah are acceptable under U.S. law and others are not, and those who practice Shariah in this country do so voluntarily. Nobody in the U.S. has the legal right to impose their religious beliefs on another person or group, and when they do (as has happened from time to time) it is treated as a crime.

Believe me, I'm not starry-eyed about Shariah and I would not wish it on anyone I cared about, especially any woman. But the laws in this country already protect them. Extra legislation is unnecessary.

Comment: As a Commissioned Pastoral Minister since 2008, I have noticed bishops show little interest in actually utilizing the people who have graduated and have earned certificates.   Our diocese has literally over 100 certified lay ministers who not only completed the three year formation, but for the most part paid for it themselves.  The program itself was excellent with instructors drawn from  religious, and laypeople from local colleges.  Upon graduation  the participants were inspired and galvanized to start making  a difference in their parishes, only to discover their pastors had no idea what to do with them, even though the vast majority would be working for no salary.  Apparently there was no preparation given to priests on how to benefit from this boon of free, qualified personnel.  As a result the program faltered leaving many eager, well educated  people with  little to do.
